message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Secure Containment Control for Multi-UAV Systems by Fixed-Time Convergent Reinforcement Learning
Paper Abstract: This article concerns the secure containment control problem for multiple autonomous aerial vehicles. The cyber attacker can manipulate control commands, resulting in containment failure in the position loop. Within a zero-sum graphical game framework, secure containment controllers and malicious attackers are regarded as game players, and the attack-defense process is recast as a min-max optimization problem. Acquiring optimal distributed secure control policies requires solving the game-related Hamilton-Jacobi-Isaacs (HJI) equations. Based on the critic-only neural network (NN) structure, the reinforcement learning (RL) method is employed in solving coupled HJI equations. The fixed-time convergence technique is introduced to improve the convergence rate of RL, and the experience replay mechanism is utilized to relax the persistence of excitation condition. The associated NN convergence and closed-loop stability are analyzed. In the attitude loop, the optimal feedback control law is obtained by solving Hamilton-Jacobi-Bellman equations using the fixed-time convergent RL method. The simulation example and the quadrotor experiment are given to show the effectiveness of the proposed scheme.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

I've successfully performed a web search for "Reinforcement Learning." Here's a summary of the key information found:

## Overview

Reinforcement learning (RL) is concerned with how an intelligent agent should take actions in a dynamic environment in order to maximize a reward signal.(no content)Reinforcement learning is one of the three basic machine learning paradigms, alongside supervised learning and unsupervised learning.

## Key Concepts

While supervised learning and unsupervised learning algorithms attempt to discover patterns in labeled and unlabeled data, reinforcement learning involves training an agent through interactions with its environment.(no content)The agent makes decisions between trying new actions to learn more about the environment (exploration), or using current knowledge of the environment to take the best action (exploitation).

## Applications

Reinforcement learning has been applied successfully to various problems, including energy storage, robot control, photovoltaic generators, backgammon, checkers, Go (AlphaGo), and autonomous driving systems.(no content)Deep reinforcement learning has been used for a diverse set of applications including robotics, video games, natural language processing, computer vision, education, transportation, finance and healthcare.

## Notable Achievements

AlphaGo, a computer program trained with deep RL to play Go, became the first computer Go program to beat a human professional Go player without handicap on a full-sized 19×19 board.

I've completed the web search for "Unmanned aerial vehicle." Here's what I found:

## Definition and Overview

An unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) or unmanned aircraft system (UAS), commonly known as a drone, is an aircraft with no human pilot, crew, or passengers on board, but rather is controlled remotely or is autonomous.

## Key Characteristics

Unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) include both autonomous (capable of operating without human input) drones and remotely piloted vehicles (RPVs), and a UAV is capable of controlled, sustained level flight and is powered by a jet, reciprocating, or electric engine.

## History

UAVs were originally developed through the twentieth century for military missions, with significant development of drones starting in the 1900s, originally focused on providing practice targets for training military personnel.

## Modern Applications

Unmanned aerial vehicles are used across the world for civilian, commercial, as well as military applications. These applications include aircraft maintenance, surveillance, search and rescue, crop monitoring, disaster response, and many other uses.

## Commercial Development

In 2006, the United States Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) allowed the usage of unmanned aerial vehicles inside civilian airspace with specific regulations. In 2013, DJI released the first model of the Phantom drone, priced at $629, and the DJI Phantom was considered one of the most influential consumer drone products ever made.

Links: [{"title":"Optimal control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Optimal_control"},{"title":"Pseudospectral optimal control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pseudospectral_optimal_control"},{"title":"Control (optimal control theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_(optimal_control_theory)"},{"title":"Unscented optimal control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unscented_optimal_control"},{"title":"Stochastic control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stochastic_control"},{"title":"Machine learning control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Machine_learning_control"},{"title":"Coherent control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coherent_control"},{"title":"H-infinity methods in control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/H-infinity_methods_in_control_theory"},{"title":"PROPT - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PROPT"},{"title":"Witsenhausen's counterexample - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Witsenhausen's_counterexample"}]

I've completed a web search for "Optimal control." Here's a summary of the key information found:

## Overview

Optimal control theory is a branch of control theory that deals with finding a control for a dynamical system over a period of time such that an objective function is optimized.(no content)It has numerous applications in science, engineering and operations research.

## Practical Examples

For example, the dynamical system might be a spacecraft with controls corresponding to rocket thrusters, and the objective might be to reach the Moon with minimum fuel expenditure.(no content)Or the dynamical system could be a nation's economy, with the objective to minimize unemployment; the controls in this case could be fiscal and monetary policy.

## Key Concepts

A control problem includes a cost functional that is a function of state and control variables. An optimal control is a set of differential equations describing the paths of the control variables that minimize the cost function.(no content)The optimal control can be derived using Pontryagin's maximum principle (a necessary condition also known as Pontryagin's minimum principle or simply Pontryagin's principle), or by solving the Hamilton–Jacobi–Bellman equation (a sufficient condition).

## Historical Background

The method is largely due to the work of Lev Pontryagin and Richard Bellman in the 1950s, after contributions to calculus of variations by Edward J. McShane.

## Modern Applications

Recent developments include machine learning approaches and pseudospectral methods for solving optimal control problems, as well as applications in stochastic control, quantum systems, and autonomous vehicles.

I've completed a web search for "Optimal control." Here's a summary of the key information found:

## Overview

Optimal control theory is a branch of control theory that deals with finding a control for a dynamical system over a period of time such that an objective function is optimized.(no content)It has numerous applications in science, engineering and operations research.

## Practical Examples

For example, the dynamical system might be a spacecraft with controls corresponding to rocket thrusters, and the objective might be to reach the Moon with minimum fuel expenditure.(no content)Or the dynamical system could be a nation's economy, with the objective to minimize unemployment; the controls in this case could be fiscal and monetary policy.

## Key Concepts

A control problem includes a cost functional that is a function of state and control variables. An optimal control is a set of differential equations describing the paths of the control variables that minimize the cost function.(no content)The optimal control can be derived using Pontryagin's maximum principle (a necessary condition also known as Pontryagin's minimum principle or simply Pontryagin's principle), or by solving the Hamilton–Jacobi–Bellman equation (a sufficient condition).

## Historical Background

The method is largely due to the work of Lev Pontryagin and Richard Bellman in the 1950s, after contributions to calculus of variations by Edward J. McShane.

## Modern Applications

Recent developments include machine learning approaches and pseudospectral methods for solving optimal control problems, as well as applications in stochastic control, quantum systems, and autonomous vehicles.

Web search results for query: "Neural network"

Links: [{"title":"Neural network (machine learning) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neural_network_(machine_learning)"},{"title":"Neural network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neural_network"},{"title":"Physical neural network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Physical_neural_network"},{"title":"Neural network (biology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biological_neural_network"},{"title":"Convolutional neural network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Convolutional_neural_network"},{"title":"Graph neural network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graph_neural_network"},{"title":"History of artificial neural networks - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_artificial_neural_networks"},{"title":"Energy-based generative neural network","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Energy-based_generative_neural_network"},{"title":"Feedback neural network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feedback_neural_network"},{"title":"File:Artificial Neural Network.gif","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Artificial_Neural_Network.gif"}]

## Neural Network Overview

I found comprehensive information about neural networks. Here's what I discovered:

### Definition and Basic Structure

A neural network consists of connected units or nodes called artificial neurons, which loosely model the neurons in the brain.(no content)In machine learning, a neural network is an artificial mathematical model used to approximate nonlinear functions.

### Architecture

Signals travel from the first layer (the input layer) to the last layer (the output layer), possibly passing through multiple intermediate layers (hidden layers).(no content)A network is typically called a deep neural network if it has at least two hidden layers.

### How Neural Networks Work

The behavior of the network depends on the strengths (or weights) of the connections between neurons. A network is trained by modifying these weights through empirical risk minimization or backpropagation in order to fit some preexisting dataset.

### Applications

Neural networks are used to solve problems in artificial intelligence, and have thereby found applications in many disciplines, including predictive modeling, adaptive control, facial recognition, handwriting recognition, general game playing, and generative AI.

### Historical Development

Today's deep neural networks are based on early work in statistics over 200 years ago.(no content)In 1958, psychologist Frank Rosenblatt described the perceptron, one of the first implemented artificial neural networks, funded by the United States Office of Naval Research.

I've completed a web search for "Cybersecurity attack" and found comprehensive information. Here are the key findings:

## Definition

A cyberattack occurs when there is an unauthorized action against computer infrastructure that compromises the confidentiality, integrity, or availability of its content.

## Types of Attacks

The search results reveal several categories of cybersecurity attacks:

1. **Denial-of-Service Attacks**: DoS attacks are designed to make a machine or network resource unavailable to its intended users, with attackers either denying service to individual victims or overloading the capabilities of a machine or network.

2. **Malware-Based Attacks**: Attackers attempt to find weaknesses in a system, exploit them and create malware to carry out their goals, and deliver it to the targeted system.

3. **Cyber-Kinetic Attacks**: These attacks target cyber-physical systems and cause direct or indirect physical damage, injury or death, or environmental impact solely through the exploitation of vulnerable information systems and processes.

## Who Conducts Attacks

Perpetrators of a cyberattack can be criminals, hacktivists, or states.

## Impact

Cyberattacks can cause a variety of harms to targeted individuals, organizations, and governments, including significant financial losses and identity theft.

The search results also included examples of major real-world cyberattacks, such as the 2014 Sony Pictures hack and the 2021 Health Service Executive ransomware attack in Ireland.

Links: [{"title":"Quadcopter - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quadcopter"},{"title":"Talk:Quadcopter - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Quadrotor"},{"title":"Multirotor - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multirotor"},{"title":"Unmanned aerial vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_aerial_vehicle"},{"title":"MikroKopter - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MikroKopter"},{"title":"Category:Quadcopters - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Quadcopters"},{"title":"Asisguard Songar - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asisguard_Songar"},{"title":"Davide Scaramuzza - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Davide_Scaramuzza"},{"title":"IAI Rotem L - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IAI_Rotem_L"}]

Here's what I found about quadrotor drones:

## Definition and Basic Concept

Quadcopters (also referred to as quadrotors) were historically seen as a possible solution to persistent problems in vertical flight.(no content)Quadcopters generally have two rotors spinning clockwise (CW) and two counterclockwise (CCW), with flight control provided by independent variation of the speed and hence lift and torque of each rotor. Pitch and roll are controlled by varying the net centre of thrust, with yaw controlled by varying the net torque.

## How They Work

A quadrotor hovers or adjusts its altitude by applying equal thrust to all four rotors. It adjusts its yaw by applying more thrust to rotors rotating in one direction. A quadrotor adjusts its pitch or roll by applying more thrust to one rotor (or two adjacent rotors) and less thrust to the diametrically opposite rotor.

## Modern Applications

Although quadrotor helicopters have long been flown experimentally, the configuration remained a curiosity until the arrival of the modern unmanned aerial vehicle or drone. The small size and low inertia of drones allows use of a particularly simple flight control system, which has greatly increased the practicality of the small quadrotor in this application.

## Performance Records

Here's what I found about quadrotor drones:

## Definition and Basic Concept

Quadcopters (also referred to as quadrotors) were historically seen as a possible solution to persistent problems in vertical flight.(no content)Quadcopters generally have two rotors spinning clockwise (CW) and two counterclockwise (CCW), with flight control provided by independent variation of the speed and hence lift and torque of each rotor. Pitch and roll are controlled by varying the net centre of thrust, with yaw controlled by varying the net torque.

## How They Work

A quadrotor hovers or adjusts its altitude by applying equal thrust to all four rotors. It adjusts its yaw by applying more thrust to rotors rotating in one direction. A quadrotor adjusts its pitch or roll by applying more thrust to one rotor (or two adjacent rotors) and less thrust to the diametrically opposite rotor.

## Modern Applications

Although quadrotor helicopters have long been flown experimentally, the configuration remained a curiosity until the arrival of the modern unmanned aerial vehicle or drone. Web search results for query: "Zero-sum game"

Links: [{"title":"Zero-sum game - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zero-sum_game"},{"title":"Zero-sum thinking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zero-sum_thinking"},{"title":"Game without a value - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Game_without_a_value"},{"title":"Nash equilibrium - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nash_equilibrium"},{"title":"Zermelo's theorem (game theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zermelo's_theorem_(game_theory)"},{"title":"Game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Game_theory"},{"title":"Yao's principle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Randomized_algorithms_as_zero-sum_games"},{"title":"Simultaneous game - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simultaneous_game"},{"title":"Silverman's game - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Silverman's_game"},{"title":"Non-cooperative game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Non-cooperative_game_theory"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about zero-sum games:

## Definition

A zero-sum game is a mathematical representation in game theory and economic theory of a situation that involves two competing entities, where the result is an advantage for one side and an equivalent loss for the other.(no content)In other words, player one's gain is equivalent to player two's loss, with the result that the net improvement in benefit of the game is zero.

## Key Characteristics

Zero-sum games are games in which choices by players can neither increase nor decrease the available resources. In zero-sum games, the total benefit goes to all players in a game, for every combination of strategies, and always adds to zero.(no content)Such games are distributive, not integrative; the pie cannot be enlarged by good negotiation.

## Real-World Examples

Examples of zero-sum games in daily life include games like poker, chess, sport and bridge where one person gains and another person loses, which results in a zero-net benefit for every player.(no content)In the markets and financial instruments, futures contracts and options are zero-sum games as well.

## Contrast with Non-Zero-Sum Games

In contrast, non-zero-sum describes a situation in which the interacting parties' aggregate gains and losses can be less than or more than zero.(no content)A country with an excess of bananas trading with another country for their excess of apples, where both benefit from the transaction, is in a non-zero-sum situation.

Links: [{"title":"Hamilton–Jacobi–Bellman equation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hamilton–Jacobi–Bellman_equation"},{"title":"Hamilton–Jacobi equation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hamilton–Jacobi_equation"},{"title":"Bellman equation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bellman_equation"},{"title":"Talk:Hamilton–Jacobi–Bellman equation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Hamilton–Jacobi–Bellman_equation"},{"title":"Richard E. Bellman - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richard_E._Bellman"},{"title":"Pontryagin's maximum principle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pontryagin's_maximum_principle"},{"title":"Bellman - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bellman"},{"title":"Dynamic programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dynamic_programming"},{"title":"HJB - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/?redirect=no&title=HJB"},{"title":"Hamiltonian mechanics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hamiltonian_mechanics"}]

Here's what I found about the Hamilton-Jacobi-Bellman equation:

## Overview

The Hamilton-Jacobi-Bellman (HJB) equation is a nonlinear partial differential equation that provides necessary and sufficient conditions for optimality of a control with respect to a loss function.(no content)Its solution is the value function of the optimal control problem which, once known, can be used to obtain the optimal control by taking the maximizer (or minimizer) of the Hamiltonian involved in the HJB equation.

## History

The equation is a result of the theory of dynamic programming which was pioneered in the 1950s by Richard Bellman and coworkers.(no content)The connection to the Hamilton–Jacobi equation from classical physics was first drawn by Rudolf Kálmán.

## Applications and Extensions

While classical variational problems, such as the brachistochrone problem, can be solved using the Hamilton–Jacobi–Bellman equation, the method can be applied to a broader spectrum of problems.(no content)It can be generalized to stochastic systems, in which case the HJB equation is a second-order elliptic partial differential equation.

## Computational Challenges

A major drawback is that the HJB equation admits classical solutions only for a sufficiently smooth value function, which is not guaranteed in most situations. Instead, the notion of a viscosity solution is required, in which conventional derivatives are replaced by (set-valued) subderivatives.

Web search results for query: "Experience replay"

Links: [{"title":"Hippocampal replay - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hippocampal_replay"},{"title":"Session replay - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Session_replay"},{"title":"Game replay - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Replay_review"},{"title":"Q-learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Q-learning"},{"title":"Virtual replay - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virtual_replay"},{"title":"Replay (Grimwood novel) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Replay_(Grimwood_novel)"},{"title":"Instant replay - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Instant_replay"},{"title":"Experience - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Experience"},{"title":"Tealeaf - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tealeaf"},{"title":"Replay value - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Replay_value"}]

Based on the search results, "experience replay" has multiple meanings depending on the context:

## Machine Learning / Reinforcement Learning
In machine learning, experience replay is a biologically inspired mechanism that uses a random sample of prior actions instead of the most recent action to proceed, removing correlations in the observation sequence and smoothing changes in the data distribution. This technique is commonly used in reinforcement learning algorithms like Q-learning and deep Q-networks (DQN).

## Neuroscience / Hippocampus
In neuroscience, during sleep or awake rest, replay refers to the re-occurrence of a sequence of cell activations that also occurred during activity, but the replay has a much faster time scale.(no content)Hippocampal replay has been proposed to support memory consolidation and the construction of internal "cognitive maps" of space and events.

## Web Analytics
Session replay is the ability to replay a visitor's journey on a web site or within a mobile application or web application, which can include the user's view, user input (keyboard and mouse inputs), and logs of network events or console logs.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about game theory:

## Definition and Overview

Game theory is the study of mathematical models of strategic interactions.(no content)It has applications in many fields of social science, and is used extensively in economics, logic, systems science and computer science.(no content)It is now an umbrella term for the science of rational decision making in humans, animals, and computers.

## Historical Development

Modern game theory began with the idea of mixed-strategy equilibria in two-person zero-sum games and its proof by John von Neumann.(no content)His work was followed by Theory of Games and Economic Behavior (1944), co-written with Oskar Morgenstern, which considered cooperative games of several players.(no content)Initially, game theory addressed two-person zero-sum games, in which a participant's gains or losses are exactly balanced by the losses and gains of the other participant. In the 1950s, it was extended to the study of non zero-sum games, and was eventually applied to a wide range of behavioral relations.

## Key Concepts

### Nash Equilibrium
Nash's most famous contribution to game theory is the concept of the Nash equilibrium, which is a solution concept for non-cooperative games, published in 1951. A Nash equilibrium is a set of strategies, one for each player, such that no player can improve their payoff by unilaterally changing their strategy.

### Types of Games
A game is cooperative if the players are able to form binding commitments externally enforced (e.g. through contract law). A game is non-cooperative if players cannot form alliances or if all agreements need to be self-enforcing (e.g. through credible threats).

## Recognition and Impact

John Maynard Smith was awarded the Crafoord Prize for his application of evolutionary game theory in 1999, and fifteen game theorists have won the Nobel Prize in economics as of 2020, including most recently Paul Milgrom and Robert B. Wilson.

I found the Wikipedia article on the Hamilton-Jacobi-Bellman equation. Here are the key points:

## Overview

The Hamilton-Jacobi-Bellman (HJB) equation is a nonlinear partial differential equation that provides necessary and sufficient conditions for optimality of a control with respect to a loss function.(no content)Its solution is the value function of the optimal control problem which, once known, can be used to obtain the optimal control by taking the maximizer (or minimizer) of the Hamiltonian involved in the HJB equation.

## Historical Background

The equation is a result of the theory of dynamic programming which was pioneered in the 1950s by Richard Bellman and coworkers.(no content)The connection to the Hamilton–Jacobi equation from classical physics was first drawn by Rudolf Kálmán.

## Related Concepts

In discrete-time problems, the analogous difference equation is usually referred to as the Bellman equation.(no content)It can be generalized to stochastic systems, in which case the HJB equation is a second-order elliptic partial differential equation.

## Solutions and Challenges

A major drawback is that the HJB equation admits classical solutions only for a sufficiently smooth value function, which is not guaranteed in most situations. Instead, the notion of a viscosity solution is required, in which conventional derivatives are replaced by (set-valued) subderivatives.

## Summary

**Paper Analysis Complete: Secure Containment Control for Multi-UAV Systems**

### Paper Classification
- **Type**: Contribution (proposes novel methods and techniques)

### Key Entities Identified (10 triples)

**Methods Used** (3):
- Reinforcement learning - Core algorithm for solving HJI equations
- Hamilton-Jacobi-Bellman equation - Used for optimal feedback control
- Fixed-time convergence - **Novel** technique proposed to improve RL convergence rate

**Tools & Artifacts** (2):
- Neural network (machine learning) - Critic-only structure for RL
- Quadcopter - Platform for validation experiments

**Concepts** (3):
- Game theory - Zero-sum framework for attack-defense modeling
- Zero-sum game - Specific game-theoretic formulation
- Optimal control - Foundation for control policies

**Tasks/Problems** (2):
- Unmanned aerial vehicle - Platform for secure containment control
- Cyberattack - Challenge being addressed (manipulated control commands)

### Validation Status
✅ **PASSED** - All 10 triples validated successfully with correct Wikipedia URLs and proper entity classification.

The analysis identified that this paper uses existing techniques (reinforcement learning, neural networks, game theory, HJI equations, optimal control) while proposing a novel "fixed-time convergence" technique to improve the convergence rate of the RL algorithm.
